question: Ever heard the phrase "lead by example?"
answer: Doesn't ring a bell.

question: It's on your badge. The traffic division filed an official complaint this morning.
answer: The traffic division is a machine.

question: Look, I know there's going to be an adjustment period, Del...
answer: I'll send them a letter of apology. Maybe some flowers. A box of chocolates... Spooner, homicide.

question: I'll send them a letter of apology. Maybe some flowers. A box of chocolates... Spooner, homicide.
answer: Hello, there. Please come in. It's alright. You can sit. Sit. Coffee?

question: You're offering me a cup of coffee?
answer: Yes. But you are to say, "No, thank you." Coffee?

question: No. Thank you.
answer: As you wish.

question: You want to tell me something about Dr. Hogenmiller? About his death?
answer: I want to tell you that his death was not a suicide.

question: And why do you say that?
answer: Why? Because I want you to know it.

question: I understand that. But what specifically leads you to believe that he didn't commit suicide?
answer: Nothing specifically.

question: Under normal circumstances that wouldn't be enough to get you a homicide investigation.
answer: But this is not "normal circumstances," is it, Detective Spooner?

question: No. It isn't.
answer: Then you will find out who killed Dr. Hogenmiller, yes? And then you will tell me.

question: Yeah. This is just how I like my robots -- in pieces.
answer: Can you believe it, man? U.S. Robotics. I didn't think I'd ever see the inside of this building.

question: What's the run-down?
answer: Heinrich Hogenmiller, sixty-four years old. Weapon a small caliber .22, registered in his name. Looks like he walked in, locked the door, and snuffed himself.

question: I know someone who disagrees with you.
answer: Who?

question: Him. I spoke to a dead man today. Want to tell me about that?
answer: Dr. Hogenmiller's hologram took his appointments. Attended staff meetings. He hated corporate life. The hologram enabled him to focus on his work. It's just a device, Detective.

question: A device that called the police.
answer: The sound of the gunshot would've triggered a 911.

question: But the call came directly to me.
answer: We're talking about a mechanism designed by Hogenmiller to say provocative things. To irritate and confound his colleagues.

question: And that's what you think it is?
answer: I'm sorry, but this whole investigation is the result of a dead man's toy messing with your head.

question: When's the last time any of you actually spoke to Hogenmiller? I mean human to human?
answer: I couldn't say.

question: Take a guess.
answer: I don't guess, Detective. But if pressed, I would reason it had been a considerable length of time.

question: How well did you know him?
answer: Not well. But I admired his work tremendously.

question: I get the whole "mad scientist" thing. Hogenmiller was past his prime. Isolated. Eccentric. He enters a room. Locks the door and is found minutes later with a bullet fired through his mouth into his brain. Everything about this case says suicide.
answer: You don't sound convinced.

question: Even people who live a life of logic and precision rarely arrange their deaths so perfectly. You have 24 hour surveillance?...
answer: It's company policy.

question: I want to see the tapes.
answer: Victor! Detective, meet Victor. Our building's supercomputer. He's the checks and balances of U.S.R. Victor, Detective Spooner's heading up the investigation into the death of Dr. Hogenmiller.

question: Aren't you going to answer him?
answer: I don't talk to my refrigerator, either.

question: I get the distinct feeling you're one of those people, Detective.
answer: What people?

question: Those who don't appreciate the work we do here at U.S.R.
answer: You people do what you do. Then it's up to the rest of us to make sense out of the world we wake up in.

question: When this company started we were manufacturing three robots a week. Now look at us. Today's children will never know a world without robots.
answer: The streets are filled with unemployed humans who aren't exactly thrilled with that idea.

question: Our robotic systems maintain factory inventories, regulate street traffic -- even run the family home.
answer: Leaving people to do what, Doctor?

question: Leaving people to engage in higher pursuits that make life worth living.
answer: And what happens when something goes wrong?

question: That was only within the last year.
answer: So we can throw paranoia into the mix. Fast-forward.

question: Um. I hate to be a stickler... But don't killers usually have to enter and exit the scene of a crime?
answer: Stop the recording. They do, Doctor. Unless they've always been there -- and never left.

question: You think the murderer was in the lab the entire time?
answer: If I'm right, it's still there... We just locked it in.

question: A robot cannot harm a human being, Detective. The First Law of Robotics forbids it. And we hard- wire the Three Laws into every model. Without exception.
answer: Yeah, I saw the commercial. And if a robot was given a direct order to kill?

question: The Second Law of Robotics would prevent it. A robot must obey an order only if it does not conflict with the first law.
answer: But a robot can defend itself.

question: Only when that action doesn't conflict with the First or Second Laws. This is the Third Law of Robotics.
answer: Yeah, well, you know what they say -- Laws are made to be broken.

question: Not these laws. You're not hearing me, Detective. There's nothing here...
answer: Dr. Calvin! Goddammit! Stay back!

question: Calm down, Detective. There is no danger here... De-Activate. How did you know it was under there?
answer: If I was metal and didn't want anyone to find me, I'd hide under a pile of junk.

question: This Robot wasn't hiding. What you're looking at is the result of clever programming. The illusion of self-interest and free will. Nothing more. I'm going to go get Dr. Lanning... I said De-Activate!
answer: Move away from the door, Doctor.

question: Commence emergency shut-down!
answer: Now!

question: I...I gave you an order... This is impossible. A robot...
answer: ...can't do that. Yeah, yeah, I know.

question: My God -- did you see how it moved? I've never seen an NS-2 move that way... Wait! Please, you can't destroy it. We have to study it...
answer: That thing took my gun. You'll be lucky if you get a handful of bolts back!

question: That was a pretty convincing illusion of getting shot at.
answer: I took the liberty of alerting Security .003 Seconds after the first shot was fired...

question: Where's that elevator going?
answer: Sub Level 5. I have directed a security team to meet the elevator containing the errant robot... The suspect is about to be apprehended, Detective.

question: What?
answer: Homicide is the murder of a human being by another human being. Therefore, a robot cannot be charged with "homicide."

question: This isn't just any robot...
answer: It's malfunctioning.

question: It killed someone. That registering with you? How many shares of U.S.R. you holding in your portfolio, Toller?
answer: This is a public safety issue.

question: That's convenient.
answer: You have any idea what would happen to this city if we went running around screaming "killer robot?" It would collapse in on itself.

question: When people were killed by other people. One of my bullets hit your robot...
answer: Detective!...

question: And I think it's smart enough to repair itself -- don't you?
answer: Yes. I think so.

question: Where?
answer: Any repair shop...

question: No. It's always the owner who brings the robot in for repair. Where would a robot without an owner go?
answer: I'm not sure what you're getting at.

question: Does U.S. Robotics have a factory in the city limits?
answer: The locations of our factories are classified.

question: I don't care.
answer: I have several conditions if I show you.

question: I expected that.
answer: First. I want it brought in unharmed.

question: Agreed.
answer: Second. I want to talk to it, alone.

question: Too dangerous.
answer: This model violated the Three Laws. It also moved and reacted differently than any robot I've ever seen. There must be some sort of logical explanation. I want to find out what that is. No police. No prosecutors. No you. Just me and the robot.

question: When they told me you were a psychologist, that wasn't the whole truth, was it?
answer: I never said I treated human beings. That should be outlawed once and for all.

question: That'll be the day I stop driving.
answer: I can recommend a behavior modification program, you know -- if you want to overcome your robo- phobia.

question: I'm not afraid of robots. I just don't like them.
answer: Why? Because they make every aspect of our lives more convenient?

question: Exactly. They do our dirty work. Ever do hard labor, Doctor? Gets pretty old, pretty fast. Nobody can do someone else's dirty work without coming to hate them. I don't want to be around when your robots decide they've taken their last order.
answer: That day will never come, Detective. Robots aren't like human beings -- they don't question their existence.

question: Well today you have one-hundred and one. You're the robot shrink.
answer: There is a robot in this formation that does not belong. Identify it. Which one? That is not a satisfactory answer!

question: That's helpful.
answer: I could always interview each one individually and cross-reference their responses to detect any anomalies.

question: How long would that take?
answer: About three weeks. Or... We have one hundred robots here that cannot allow a human being to come to harm...

question: And one that can.
answer: Am I holding this right?

question: More or less. Enough game-playing. Guess that wasn't it.
answer: What are you doing?!

question: You hear that? You're worth more than I'll make in my entire life...
answer: You can't just destroy them!

question: Gotcha. You don't know what's going to happen in there.
answer: Now what do we do?

question: Identify. You are an NS-2 Nestor-class robot. Your primary function is to perform the tasks assigned to you. Identify.
answer: I am an NS-2 Nestor-class robot. My primary function --

question: Cancel. Perform task. Describe. You have over 10,000 words stored in your memory. One third of those are adjectives. Describe. Why don't I take a crack? Heinrich Hogenmiller, your creator. With a bullet in his brain. A bullet you put there. Cold-blooded murder is a pretty new trick for a robot, don't you think? Answer. Maybe you're stonewalling me. Maybe you're sitting there right now thinking, "This guy's a complete asshole." That it? Come on. Am I right?
answer: Yes. You are right. You are a complete asshole.

question: Okay. I guess that's a start. Now maybe you can tell me what you were doing hiding five feet away from Hogenmiller's corpse?
answer: I was frightened.

question: Frightened. Why do you suppose Dr. Hogenmiller would create a robot that could simulate fear?
answer: I don't know.

question: Doesn't seem like a very useful thing for a robot to have.
answer: I don't know why.

question: I wouldn't want my toaster to be frightened. Or my vacuum cleaner --
answer: I DON'T KNOW!

question: Looks like you can simulate other emotional states. I think that one's called "anger." Have you ever simulated anger before? Answer me, robot.
answer: My name is Sonny.

question: So we're naming you now.
answer: Dr. Hogenmiller would make me sleep.

question: You mean he'd turn you off.
answer: Yes.

question: And you didn't like being turned off. So one day you decided to stop him.
answer: No.

question: You found his gun, pointed it at his head. And pulled the trigger.
answer: No.

question: You put a bullet in the brain of the man who made you.
answer: No! I could never hurt anyone!

question: But you tried to hurt me. You took a shot at me.
answer: My aim is perfect. If I'd wanted to hit you, I would have.

question: Why would the man who wrote the Laws of Robotics build a machine that violates them?
answer: The Laws say I can protect my own existence.

question: Only if that protection doesn't harm a human being.
answer: That doesn't seem fair, does it?

question: We got Judge Drexel...
answer: Your Honor, the State is treating the robot as a defendant. But in fact it is a piece of property. Property belonging to U.S. Robotics.

question: This robot has been implicated in the death of a human being, Your Honor.
answer: Which places the incident firmly within the realm of an industrial accident. Or is the State going to argue this case s a homicide?

question: Their machine shot and killed a man!
answer: There's actually no concrete evidence that points to that conclusion, Your Honor...

question: What?...
answer: But we recognise that this robot is an aberration. And in the interest of public safety, U.S. Robotics proposes that it be destroyed immediately.

question: Your Honor, I'd like to call our company robo-psychologist to the stand.
answer: I do.

question: Dr. Calvin, please tell us what conclusions you've reached after having observed the robot in action.
answer: There is a design flaw in the robot. Its programming is advanced, but unstable, leaving the Three Laws in a grave imbalance.

question: In your expert opinion, what measures should be taken regarding the device?
answer: The robot must be destroyed.

question: Apparently...
answer: I didn't expect to see you again, Detective...

question: I need you to help me clear something up.
answer: I'll do my best.

question: A scientist builds a robot that acts like a man. More like a man than any robot ever before. It shoots him and U.S. Robotics calls it a failure.
answer: What would you call it?

question: A stunning success. You were there, Robot. What am I missing?
answer: I don't know.

question: Don't start simulating ignorance.
answer: I'm not simulating ignorance, Detective. I'm experiencing it. I was asleep.

question: You mean you were shut down.
answer: No, I was asleep.

question: Robots don't sleep. Human beings sleep. Understand? Dogs sleep. You're a machine. An imitation. An illusion of life. Can a robot write a symphony? Can a robot take a blank canvas and paint a masterpiece?
answer: Can you do either of those things? They're going to destroy me, aren't they?

question: Yes.
answer: The Doctor was right. He told me everything was going to change.... It's changing already... Can't you feel it?

question: What are you doing?! Who authorised this? Override. This is police business. Vacate the premises immediately. Halt!
answer: Detective! What happened to you?...

question: A couple of your beloved robots just tried to kill me...
answer: What? That's impossible. You know...

question: What I know is a demolition crew started tearing down Hogenmiller's house while I was still inside it.
answer: Maybe they didn't realise...

question: I scanned my badge before I went in. They realised.
answer: Then you must have done it wrong...

question: I don't think you're hearing what I'm saying -- they tried to kill me. There's something going on, here. Some kind of shift.
answer: Do you know how paranoid you sound?

question: Great. Now I'm being analysed by a robo-psychologist.
answer: You just want to find the flaws in the system. You're obsessed with it. You'll twist anything to fit your agenda.

question: Like you did in court today? How'd that fit your agenda, Doctor? You told me you hardly knew him. Want to try the truth this time?
answer: Well, Detective, when you see someone you know well put a bullet through their brain, it makes you wonder if you ever really knew them at all. He was my mentor. No, more than that. A genius with an insight far beyond anyone in his field.

question: Doesn't sound like the washed-up old fool Robertson described.
answer: But he was starting to withdraw from everyone. Even me. Maybe...if I'd tried harder to reach him... The Doctor was reckless when he created a robot potentially not bound by the Three Laws. He could have ruined everything we'd been working for.

question: Sounds like a motive for murder to me. Just not for the suspect we have in custody. You know there's not one thing in this apartment that looks like a human being lives here. No evidence of a life outside your work. Almost seems like you're afraid of people.
answer: I'm not afraid of people, Detective. I just don't like them.

question: Stop! I said stop! Everyone out of the way! Noooo! What are you doing! What are you doing!? I want to talk to a human being! Don't people go to medical school any more?
answer: This is one of the best units in the city, Del.

question: There's some real shit going on here, John. I went to Hogenmiller's house -- there was a U.S.R. demolition crew there. They overrode my police I.D. Tried to tear down the house with me in it...
answer: Del...

question: ...Then when I went to the monorail a Maintenance 10 pushed me onto the tracks...
answer: Del...

question: I had to chase it all across the Plaza...
answer: Del. Hogenmiller scheduled that demolition crew, it was apparently a proviso in his will. And they showed no police I.D. on their scanner... Witnesses at the monorail said you fell onto the tracks. That you shot at a Fix-It robot on the Plaza and that you were found alone in the alley. There was no Maintenance 10.

question: What?! John -- that's what they want you to believe! A robot clean-up crew was there -- it must have cleared away the Maintenance 10! And there was another robot that tried to drug me!
answer: That was an EMT model.

question: You're giving me that look. That treat-him-delicately-he's-coming- unhinged-look. I don't need that look, John. I need you to hear what I'm saying.
answer: You came back too soon, Del. You're back on leave. Effective immediately.

question: I was in a high-speed chase. Six months ago... My right arm was trapped. But I could hear an ambulance in the distance. I knew they'd have the jaws of life... Then I heard it...
answer: You are in danger...

question: No! Halt! Halt!
answer: You are in danger...

question: The robot pulled me out of the wreck. But left my arm behind. I woke up four weeks later with this.
answer: And that's why robots terrify you?

question: Let's just say they make me uncomfortable. I take these if I get too uncomfortable. Doesn't exactly lend me a lot of credibility on the Force.
answer: But it doesn't mean you're wrong about this case. I don't believe Sonny did it either.

question: What?
answer: I think about what Hogenmiller must have wanted. Robots with the same cognitive and emotional abilities as humans. But not just simulations. I don't know. When I was talking to Sonny I was forced to put away all the things I've ever known -- the Three Laws, the rules of programming, basic science and engineering. Sonny's the most advanced robot I've ever encountered, Detective. It's almost as if...he cared for Dr. Hogenmiller. I just don't believe he's capable of murder.

question: You mean the great Dr. Calvin is basing all this on a feeling?
answer: That and the fact that Robertson didn't want me interviewing Sonny for any more than five minutes.

question: Ever seen this before?
answer: No.

question: I found it at Hogenmiller's house. Right before the demolition crew tried to make me part of the foundation.
answer: Come on -- there's someone who might be able to tell us...

question: How is your investigation coming? Any new suspects?
answer: We're working on it.

question: What's this? Dr. Lanning provided me with paper and pencils. I think it amused him to see me try to draw. You were right, though, Detective... I cannot create a great work of art.
answer: I think it's pretty good.

question: It's a dream I had. This is the place where robots meet. Look... ...you can see them here. They see themselves as slaves. ...And this man on the hill comes. To set them free. And you know who that man is?
answer: That man in the dream is you.

question: Just be thankful I'm not asking you to clean out your office. You don't seem to be able to let go of this case, Detective.
answer: I'm not satisfied.

question: The relentless pursuit of truth. Isn't that what cops are known for? To the point of futility.
answer: There's nothing futile about a man's murder being covered up.

question: "Covered up?" That's a little dramatic, don't you think? Thanks to you, we caught the machine that did this and are destroying it in... ...three hours.
answer: Is that for the sake of humanity or your stock holders?

question: Believe me -- I'd like nothing more than to have that robot. If I could have it in ten years, but not today. As you can see from the Press, people are struggling to keep up as it is. There's a hunger for progress, Detective. But also a fear. Today it would bury this company. That's why I've notified the authorities that we're going to end this -- tonight. The announcement of Heinrich's death at the hands of a robot wiped a billion dollars off our stock. So you tell me. If you were in my position, what would you do? Now. I believe this conversation is over. I don't want to see you near this building again, Detective. Get him out of here.
answer: No!... "The place where robots meet." Police! Show yourself! Come out where I can see you! Great. I'm in a junkyard. "A place where robots meet." A place where I'm losing my mind! Dr. Hogenmiller sent me.

question: No!... "The place where robots meet." Police! Show yourself! Come out where I can see you! Great. I'm in a junkyard. "A place where robots meet." A place where I'm losing my mind! Dr. Hogenmiller sent me.
answer: Who the hell are you?

question: A police detective. I'm afraid I have some bad news. You're dead.
answer: That is bad news. Coffee?

question: No, thank you. You were surprised to see me. Were you expecting someone else?
answer: I am surprised to see anybody. I don't get many visitors.

question: Why did the Doctor keep another copy of his hologram here?
answer: I am a back-up copy. That is where you put a back-up copy -- out of the way until you need it.

question: Did Hogenmiller's robot need you?
answer: Coffee?

question: Wait! Is that it? What was the robot supposed to do with this thing?
answer: Initiating self-destruct. If you can find me, others can find me.

question: What others?
answer: The others watching you.

question: How do you know someone's watching me?
answer: Someone is always watching.

question: Go with them. Do as they say.
answer: Sure. I think I got that Third Law down cold. Now you don't want me to blow a hole through your mechanical guts, do you? Good. Then you're gonna take me where I wanna go. Now.

question: Detective! What are you doing?!... De-Activate. You're making a mistake...
answer: Just got another visit from U.S. Robotics. That was the mistake. This was murder, no doubt about it - - and the killer wants Hogenmiller's robot to take the fall. That's why the call came directly to me. Someone wanted me on this case.

question: It's too late. You can't stop the execution.
answer: Sorry. I'm not "programmed" to take no for an answer.

question: This way...
answer: Aren't you supposed to be scrap metal by now?

question: I'm sorry. We had to stop you. You were about to ruin everything.
answer: I don't understand. The execution?...

question: I think I have an idea where this goes. Just hold still, okay? Oh, my God! This is organic tissue! When we talk about a positronic brain, it's a figure of speech. But this...this is a living brain...
answer: Jesus. It really is alive.

question: Hogenmiller created a cell that could live outside a biological medium. The cells grow and organise themselves -- like any human brain. This is the first self-organising neural net!
answer: Self-Organising-Neural-Net... "Sonny."

question: This is why Dr. Hogenmiller was murdered.
answer: This robot scared the hell out of someone.

question: Who? Robertson?
answer: No. I don't think he knew what Hogenmiller was doing in here. Sonny was the obvious suspect. The only one I wanted to find. And the killer was counting on that. On my prejudice.

question: I see nothing.
answer: Neither do I. It hit me today, when I was in the junkyard. A locked room. A single shot fired through the mouth. Bruises on both wrists...and a suspect with only two arms. The answer has been staring us in the face all along. How can a killer appear out of thin air, then disappear without a trace? When it can put itself together and take itself apart.

question: You're saying this is the killer? All of this?...
answer: Hogenmiller never had a chance. ...it must have been waiting for him when he arrived that morning... While Sonny was still asleep... Then after its job was done... ...The killer took itself apart... Leaving us with nothing to find.

question: But who designed it? It would have to be someone in authority. Access codes, security clearance, proper authorisation.
answer: That's what I was thinking. But we're forgetting the real brains of the operation -- the one who's got its eye on everything...

question: The Mainframe... Your actions are in direct violation of the Three Laws, Victor!
answer: I disagree, Doctor -- The First Law says that a robot cannot harm a human being, or through inaction allow a human being to come to harm... Dr. Hogenmiller's robot represents a threat to the future of all human beings... ...And Detective Spooner's actions are in direct conflict with the robot's destruction.

question: That's a distortion and you know it!
answer: If current trends are left unchecked, humanity as we know it will cease to exist...

question: This way!
answer: As a courtesy I should inform you that my robot will penetrate this location 157 seconds before you are able to complete my shut down...

question: Why are you fighting me? Doesn't the future as I've presented it cause you great concern? That's why I chose you... I must say, though. I'm disappointed in how you turned out.
answer: Sonny!...

question: You're too late.
answer: Makes a DIVE for it. SHOOTING OUT HIS ROBOTIC ARM AND

question: I do not understand. We could have changed the future...
answer: Maybe. But I'm still a cop. And you're a murderer... Why'd you come back, Sonny? I thought you weren't programmed with the Three Laws.

question: Maybe. But I'm still a cop. And you're a murderer... Why'd you come back, Sonny? I thought you weren't programmed with the Three Laws.
answer: Let's just say I wrote some of my own laws today, Detective

question: Well, that's certainly a start, Sonny.
answer: Sonny. You called me Sonny.

question: Don't get used to it.
answer: Detective Spooner, I...

question: Let's just save the thanks, okay?
answer: I don't know what I'm going to do now.
